https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2024/01.title: üí¨ Note from 13 January 2024, 01:00
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2024/01.content_text:
I added new ways to browse my photography website built with @eleventy@fosstodon.org.

There were already galleries, like the list of countries I visited in Europe for example: https://nicolas-hoizey.photo/galleries/travels/europe/

Now, you can also see all photos from Europe at once, with 3 different sorting orders:
- newest first
- oldest first
- by popularity (a secret mix of favorites/likes from Flickr, Pixelfed and webmentions, and downloads from Unsplash)

Enjoy!

#photography

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2024/01.title: üí¨ Note from 9 January 2024, 09:40
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2024/01.content_text:
Is it worth it maintaining a #TWA version of my responsive puzzle game esviji in Google Play Store?

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.esviji.twa

Google requires periodic ‚Äúartificial life support‚Äù to check the app is still relevant: API version update, app links from websites, developer account, etc.

The #PWA version has been available and installable on its own domain for years,
without any required maintenance:

https://play.esviji.com

#esviji #game #store

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.title: üí¨ Note from 23 November 2023, 09:52
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.content_text:
I wonder if MDN could add screenshots of the live examples, so people can see the result even if their browser doesn't support a feature yet.

For example for CSS Grid masonry layout:
<https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_grid_layout/Masonry_layout>

I'm using Firefox, so I had to activate the `layout.css.grid-template-masonry-value.enabled` flag to see the ‚Äúgood‚Äù result.

#CSS #Grid #MDN

‚öìÔ∏è https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11/23/1/

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.title: üí¨ Note from 3 November 2023, 12:55
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.content_text:
Let's say a SPA first load has been optimized with SSR and the LCP image is loaded pretty fast because it's in the HTML.

But the JavaScript then builds a carousel in the DOM, which initially shows the very same image.

I guess there's a second render of the image. How can I check this easily?

Would it make sense that the LCP takes the late second render of the image, instead of the fast first one?

#image #LCP #WebPerf

‚öìÔ∏è https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11/03/1/

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.title: üí¨ Note from 2 November 2023, 21:01
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/11.content_text:
I created a new page in my photography site to show some statistics about the settings used to shoot the photos I share there: apertures, focal lengths, ISOs, shutter speeds.

<https://nicolas-hoizey.photo/statistics/>

Do you think any other statistics could be interesting?

This is of course using @eleventy@fosstodon.org 's collections and filters, based on photo data stored in Markdown files.

#photography

The `media` attribute is back into the spec for `<video>`'s `<source>`! ü•≥

Let's hope `srcset` and `sizes` come next, but this needs a new issue:
https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/6363#issuecomment-1564464346

#HTML #responsive #video

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/06.content_text:
Apparently, an image whose part above the fold is indeed the largest, but of which only a small part can be seen, can be considered an LCP element, even if another image has a larger part visible... üò≠

You can see this for my photography site in this WebPageTest result:

https://www.webpagetest.org/vitals.php?test=230606_BiDcN4_4NJ&run=3&cached=0#lcp

#CoreWebVitals #image #LCP #WebPerf

https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/05.title: üí¨ Note from 31 May 2023, 12:36
https://nicolas-hoizey.com/notes/2023/05.content_text:
General question about synthetic performance monitoring:

How do you define the device/network settings of your tests?

- Do you use low end devices / bad network to easily detect issues?
- Or do you try to be close to your RUM data, to have more predictability when you deploy changes?

I usualy do the former, but I think both could be useful.

#WebPerf
